Supporting High-Quality Growth Agenda 
Post-COVID-19 through Institutional Reforms 
(PRC TA Report 54085) 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will require a total of 34 person-
months of consulting services (6 individual national consultants for a total of 24 person-months, 
and 4 individual international consultants for a total of 10 person-months). The consultants will be 
engaged in accordance with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and its associated procurement staff instructions. With particular 
reference to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), any need for travel shall be assessed by ADB 
and the consultant using ADB’s advice at the time of travel. Subject to ADB’s approval, the 
consultant may use remote video technology meetings to replace face-to-face meetings as 
considered necessary. A summary of consulting services required is provided in the Table.

2.  Public Administration/Decentralization/Local Government Specialist (international, 
2.5 person-months, intermittent) The specialist will have a degree, preferably a doctoral degree, 
in either public finance, public administration, economics or public policy, with at least 15 years of 
experience in public financial management or closely related fields, preferably including prior 
experience in the region. Specific responsibilities include the following:

2   
 
 
(i)  engage closely with the relevant counterparts in the National Development and 
Reform Commission (NDRC); 
(ii)  prepare a policy paper on improving basic public service delivery performance 
conducted  with  diagnostic  studies  to  inform  the  establishment  of  effective 
mechanisms to allocate, measure, and monitor service delivery performance and 
accountability across levels of government; 
(iii)  conduct  comparative  assessments  of  international  experiences  and  sharing  of 
international practices on the intergovernmental fiscal relations and performance 
monitoring of public services; 
(iv)  develop  performance  dimensions  supporting green  recovery  and  inclusive  and 
sustainable development; and  
(v)  deliver capacity development through the design and delivery of training courses on 
the implementation of the standardized public service monitoring system, which will 
be piloted in selected cities and counties.   
 
2.  Duration of the assignment and key deliverables. The assignment is planned for 2.5 
person-months, over the implementation period of the project. The assignment will comprise a 
combination of field-work and home-based work. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic and related 
travel restrictions, detailed planning of field visits is not possible at this stage and will be done 
later. Deliverables include technical reports related to items (ii)–(iv). In addition, the consultant will 
provide 6-monthly updates on (i) and (v). 
 
3.  Public Administration/Local Government Specialist (9 person-months, intermittent) 
The specialist will have a degree, preferably a masters degree, in either public finance, public 
administration, economics or public policy, with at least 8 years of experience in public financial 
management or closely related fields, preferably including prior experience in the region. Specific 
responsibilities include the following:  
 
(i)  support the engagement and coordination with the relevant counterparts in the 
NDRC; 
(ii)  support preparation of the policy paper on improving basic public service delivery 
performance conducted with diagnostic studies to inform the establishment of 
effective  mechanisms  to  allocate,  measure,  and  monitor  service  delivery 
performance and accountability across levels of government; 
(iii)  support  preparation of the performance dimensions supporting green recovery 
and inclusive and sustainable development; and  
(iv)  support capacity development through the design and delivery of training courses 
on the implementation of the standardized public service monitoring system, which 
will be piloted in selected cities and counties.   
 
4.  Duration of the assignment and key deliverables. The assignment is planned for 9 
person-months, over the implementation period of the project. The assignment will comprise a 
combination of field-work and home-based work. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic and related 
travel restrictions, detailed planning of field visits is not possible at this stage and will be done 
later. Deliverables include inputs to the technical reports related to items (ii)–(iii). In addition, the 
consultant will provide 6-monthly updates on (i) and (iv). 
 
5.  Public Financial Management Specialist/Public Finance Economist (international, 
2.5 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will have a degree, preferably a doctoral 
degree, in either public finance, public administration, economics or public policy, with at least 15

3 
years of experience in public financial management or closely related fields, preferably including 
prior experience in the region. Specific responsibilities include the following:  
 
(i)  engage closely with the relevant counterparts in the NDRC; 
(ii)  review  the  macroeconomic  and  fiscal  underpinning  of  the  current  budget 
management  cycle  (medium  term  fiscal  framework,  medium  term  budget 
framework, medium term debt strategy) across different tiers of government; 
(iii)  analyze the impacts of COVID-19 on the development financing needs across 
different tiers of government;  
(iv)  analyze  all  elements  of  the  current  budget  cycle  management  process 
(preparation,  formulation,  execution,  financial  control,  accounting,  auditing); 
special attention should be given to measures that are in place to ensure an 
optimal strategic allocation of resources and optimum operational efficiency (value 
for money) in the delivery of services; 
(v)  formulate  recommendations  for  further  strengthening  of  public  expenditure 
management arrangements and practices for service delivery;  
(vi)  provide support for the implementation of identified institutional strengthening 
measures; and 
(vii)  identify possible areas for support from ADB.  
 
6.  Duration of the assignment and key deliverables. The assignment is planned for 2.5 
person-months, over the implementation period of the project. The assignment will comprise a 
combination of field-work and home-based work. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic and related 
travel restrictions, detailed planning of field visits is not possible at this stage and will be done 
later. Deliverables include a technical report related to items (ii)–(vii).  
 
7.  Market  Regulation  Specialist—Legal  (international,  2.5  person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist will have at least 10 years of experience in international market 
access and regulation related work in developing countries. The specialist will hold a minimum of 
a master’s degree in law, finance, or a related field applicable to this position. Experience in 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) is desirable. Specific responsibilities include the following:  
 
(i)  engage closely with the relevant counterparts in the NDRC; 
(ii)  assess of major legal and regulatory barriers and challenges for establishing a 
unified market access system in the PRC completed; 
(iii)  review of international legal and regulatory practices and current market access 
and management systems providing policy recommendations on establishing a set 
of national unified market access rules and systems; 
(iv)  support international policy dialogue through fora and seminars on the design and 
establishment of unified rules and institutional systems.  
(v)  prepare a guidance paper on expanding fair market access for both domestic and 
international investors, with the service industry as pilot.  
 
8.  Duration of the assignment and key deliverables. The assignment is planned for 2.5 
person-months over the implementation period of the project. The assignment will comprise a 
combination of field-work and home-based work. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic and related 
travel restrictions, detailed planning of field visits is not possible at this stage and will be done 
later. Deliverables include inputs to the technical reports related to items (ii)–(iv). In addition, the 
consultant will provide 6-monthly updates on (i).

9.  Market  Regulation  Specialist—Economist  (international,  2.5  person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist will have at least 10 years of experience in international market 
access and regulation related work in developing countries. The specialist will hold a minimum of 
a master’s degree in economics, public finance, law, or a related field applicable to this position. 
Experience in People’s Republic of China (PRC) is desirable. Specific responsibilities include the 
following:  
 
(i)  engage closely with the relevant counterparts in the NDRC; 
(ii)  assess major institutional and economic barriers and challenges for establishing a 
unified market access system in the PRC completed; 
(iii)  review    international  practices  and  current  market  access  and  management 
systems providing policy recommendations on establishing a set of national unified 
market access rules and systems; 
(iv)  support international policy dialogue through fora and seminars on the design and 
establishment of unified rules and institutional systems; and 
(v)  prepare a guidance paper on expanding fair market access for both domestic and 
international investors, with the service industry as pilot.  
 
10.  Duration of the assignment and key deliverables. The assignment is planned for 2.5 
person-months  over the implementation period of the project. The assignment will comprise a 
combination of field-work and home-based work. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic and related 
travel restrictions, detailed planning of field visits is not possible at this stage and will be done 
later. Deliverables include inputs to the technical reports related to items (ii)–(iv). In addition, the 
consultant will provide 6-monthly updates on (i). 
 
11.  Market Regulation Specialist—Legal (national, 4.5 person-months, intermittent). 
The specialist will have at least 10 years of experience in international market access and 
regulation related work in developing countries. The specialist will hold a minimum of a master’s 
degree in law, economics, or a related field applicable to this position. Experience in People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) is desirable. Specific responsibilities include the following:  
 
(i)  support the engagement and coordination with relevant counterparts in the NDRC; 
(ii)  provide substantive inputs to the assessment on the major legal and regulatory 
barriers and challenges for establishing a unified market access system in the PRC 
completed; 
(iii)  contribute to the review of international practices and current market access and 
management systems providing policy recommendations on establishing a set of 
national unified market access rules and systems; 
(iv)  support international policy dialogue through fora and seminars on the design and 
establishment of unified rules and institutional systems; and 
(v)  contribute to the preparation of a guidance paper on expanding fair market access 
for both domestic and international investors, with the service industry as pilot. 
 
12.  Duration of the assignment and key deliverables. The assignment is planned for 4.5 
person-months over the implementation period of the project. The assignment will comprise a 
combination of field-work and home-based work. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic and related 
travel restrictions, detailed planning of field visits is not possible at this stage and will be done 
later. Deliverables include inputs to the technical reports related to items (ii)–(iv). In addition, the 
consultant will provide 6-monthly updates on (i).

establishment of unified rules and institutional systems; and

15.  TA Coordinator (national, 6 person-months, intermittent) The consultant should have 
an  academic  and  professional  background  in  economics  or  public  administration.  Strong 
communication and organizational skills, and a demonstrated focus on responding to clients’ 
needs are key. The consultant will assist the responsible ADB officer with the coordination and 
strengthening of all activities under this TA. He/she will do so through a combination of technical, 
administrative and organizational support.  The consultant will report to the responsible ADB 
Officer. In particular, the consultant, in close consultation with ADB’s project officer, will perform 
the following tasks:  
 
(i)  coordinate TA management activities, resources, and information. Act as the first 
liaison point between the ADB and the NDRC; 
(ii)  assist with the coordination between consultants working on different assignments 
under the TA, including the organization and facilitation of monthly meetings and 
ensuring the consistency and coherence of consultancy outputs; 
(iii)  organize inception workshop and inception report within one month of beginning 
assignment; and 
(iv)  liaise  with  translators/interpreters  and  assist  with  contractual  arrangements 
as/when required. 
 
16.  Duration of the assignment and key deliverables. The assignment is planned for 6 
person-months over the implementation period of the project.
